text: On tap @ The Growler. Looks more or less flawless this. A glowing orange cloudy looking beer with a big lasting and lacing cartoon looking head. Smells kinda mildish. A little orange peel, traces of wheat and white sugar. Kinda mild Id say. Not bad though. Tastes a lot better. And a lot more. It has a nice oily texture in the mouth and its just about average on the carbonation. Creamy almost in the mouth. Sweet citrussy. White sugar, some needles, a little oaky mouthdrying thing. Hints of faint old fruits and vanilla. Quite tasty and quite good. 19.06.2017
Excellent. Orange with white head. Coffee heavy on the tongue and nose. Kinda sweet. Booze hidden well. Had this on draft at Jerrys in Andersonville as part of a flight.

Hazy gold. 
Medium body, lightly flavored, smooth texture, hot and low carbonation mouthfeel, average length. 
Mildly bitter, off dry. 
Malty, herbal, spicy. 
Typical, tasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cork & cage bottle, dated 5/19/16. Pours clear golden-amber with a tight, 1-finger white head. Aroma of fruit esters with notes of vanilla and coffee. Full-bodied with a bit of oil to it. Some boozy astringency to the finish, but quite restrained. Flavor of caramel with a wood note. Mild note of coffee at the back.

Corked bottle courtesy of BrianCloudy light amber color. The cold brew produces a mild earthy aroma, ancho chilies, vanilla (from the bourbon). The body is lean, moderately sweet, with high alcohol perception; delicate malt base, a bit earthy and grassy; no Tripel character, no bourbon evidence (besides the booze); some vegetable bitterness in the final.Ungraceful brew, uncoordinated, and rather unpleasant.

Cloudy orange color with a white head that lasts. Aroma is coffee, lighter fruits, pale malt, yeast. Medium bodied, coffee flavor covers up a lot of what else is going on, virtually no barrel notes. Overpriced as are almost all Allagash beers.
Bottle (750ml $19). Light golden with small white head. Muted aroma. Very light bourbon and some sweet fruitiness. Taste is tripel with coffee. What can say. I personally much prefer the Curieux.
Draft. Golden beer with a whitish head. Bourbon aroma. Bourbon and coffee flavor with fruitiness. Bourbon and fruitiness lingers with light coffee.

Coffee, oak, slightly tart apple core nose. Cloudy amber, thick head, nice lace. Bourbon, coffee, apple core. Full body, easy carbonation. The coffee addition kind of smooths out the rough edges of the bourbon.

750ml bottle at Brians office. Bottled on 2016-05-19. Pours a hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is green pepper, coffee, some spices. Taste is quite smooth, similar to aroma, some bourbon notes. Just an ok.

Hazy, tan, no head. This has a lot of coffee on the nose, touch of that tripel accent though it is definitely subordinated to the coffee. On the palate, the coffee again is really quite strong. The tripel lends some nice mellow phenols and a thick pale malt character. The barrel is nowhere to be found. The coffee almost seems like a cover up - the beer isnt bad at all but the coffee is really incongruous to me.
[2/4/17] Draught/Bottle at Extreme Beer Fest in Boston. Golden. Coffee, vanilla, fruitiness, sweet, some alcohol.

Taste: smooth, big barley malt, coffee, woody, rich notes. Boozy bourbon, coffee bean nose. Honey/Amber color, semi clear, with a refine head of delicate lattice of lace. Medium/Full body. Alcohol sneaks up on you.

Bottle from John. Pours clear light orange lots of foamy head lots of lacing. Nose is smoky, roasted grain, sweet. Flavours are candi sugar, roasted coffee, smoke malt. Taste medium sweet, light bitter. Full body, lively carbonation and super alcohol hot finish.
Bottle. Pours a hazy golden orange with a small lacy white head. Aroma of coffee, bourbon and caramel. Flavor of fresh coffee beans, bourbon, belgian yeast, vanilla and caramel.

Bottle - 750mL corked and caged. Amber bodied with suspended particles floating about. Medium frothy white head. Aroma is more of a pure tripel with fruit, yeast, sweet malt, grains and soft booze. Taste is more sweet malt, soft booze, candied fruit, yeast, spices and coffee notes. Body is medium with a dense, bubbly carbonation and a slightly dry finish. Ends with more sweet malt, light caramel, candied fruit, soft spices, grains and coffee notes.

On tap at at Rattle n Hum in NYC. Pours an orange body with a medium white head. Zillions of small bubbles make lacing down the glass. Aroma is of coffee, Belgian candi sugar, and light hops. Tastes of coffee, hops, and goodness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured an orange color with a white head. Aroma was of coffee beans, light lemony acidity, belgian candy sweetness. Flavor similar, base and coffee just didnt meld well for me.

Bottle, caged and corked. Murky pour of gritty orange color, opaque, a firm 1/4" topping. Nice aroma, sweet and malty. This drinks with a unique character, rich sugary and brothy. The coffee adds a nice earthiness to it, balancing off what would be a big, fruity beer, to make this a meaty goliath. Very good. (#6378, 10/23/2016)

On tap at 2SP Wilmington. Golden pour, bourbon on the nose. Some light fruit, honey and trippel flavors, but theres a lot of bourbon, no lie. These styles work though. I dont often like the bourbon barrel aged beers, but this is fine.

Pretty gold pour w/ a retaining white head & some lacing. The aroma is mainly dominated by the bourbon while the taste leans towards the coffee. It is complex & delicious! It is remarkably smooth at 10+% & scary drinkable. This is an awesome beer!

On tap at Blind Tiger, pours a hazy copper with a small white head. Aroma brings out loads of coffee upfront, followed by whiskey and light candied sugar. Flavour is complex as hell in a way youd never expect from such a description, with Belgian yeast, coffee beans, and whiskey. Boozy and burning, but not in a detracting way. Fantastic stuff.

Pours clear gold into a snifter. Bright white head with good retention recedes leaving spot lacing. Vanilla, chocolate and espresso aromas. Thin with sweet mocha and vanilla upfront warming to espresso in the lasting, sweet vanilla and bourbon finish. I wanted to like this one more...

Maine Rate #150. Belgian Strong Ale #50. Draft at Ale House earlier this afternoon. From notes. Pours golden brown with an off white head. Aroma is caramel malt, honey, coffee, whiskey, Belgian yeast. Flavor follows. Surprisingly light and easy to drink for the abv. Just like Curieaux with a hint of nutty cold brew coffee Nice.

Lightly boozy, strong coffee aroma. Hazed golden with lacy white head. Starts with a bit of coffee citrus edge then becomes a light bourbony boozy then finished with some coffee. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at Marshall Stack. Coffee in the nose with bourbon, malt and booze. Medium body heavy retention and full of dynamic flavors; booze, caramel, bourbon and coffee. Packed with alc. Its good.
Bottle gift from SJ. Nice notes of Bourbon, bread, Belgian spice and coffee. Pretty solid.

Bomber from Whole Foods Fair Lakes
Aroma: coffee, caramel, bourbon
Appearance: hazy golden with a white head
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: medium body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish, 

Tasty

Draught at Beer Hall SF. Golden color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, ripe fruits, coffee, bourbon, yeast, earthy notes and a bit of hops. Bitter finish with citrus, ripe fruits, yeast, coffee, a bit of hops and bourbon. Excellent, unorthodox tripel.
Draft at the brewery, 7/26/16. Golden-orange. Big coffee and booze aroma. Caramel and bournon. Similar flavor. Full bodied and fairly hot. Nice sipper. You can taste the ABV on this one for sure.

Looks like Curieux, perhaps a touch darker with less head. Still complex, but the flavors of the base are muted...fruity Belgian, bourbon and vanilla. Coffee up front in the nose and palate, not overdone. A lil sweet. Tasty brew.
750 ml bottle in a glass. Aroma toast, roasty, coffee. Appearance hazy, orange with medium head. Taste is more bourbon, but not overpowering. Overall a tasty sipper.

Draft at Arlington. Poured a hazed orangey amber with a foamy white head. Aroma of cold coffee, barrel, hint of bourbon, chocolate, toast. Flavor is a litle more bourbny along with some grains. Fuller body, heat throughlut but just average lingering on the aftertaste itself.

750ml bottle in a plastic cup. Pours amber with a white head. Aroma of coffee, some light bourbon and oak, pale and caramel malts, and some light notes of Belgian yeast. Flavor the same with a decent blend. The sweet beer and coffee and (light) bourbon barrel notes dont really blend perfectly. Average texture. Decent overall.
750 cc from Whole Foods PM. Pours hazy copper with fluffy, white head. Nose is coffee, florals, malt, yeast. Tastes floral, hoppy, with notes of coffee, yeast, and some spice. Complex finish.

On tap at the brewery. Pours orange with fluffy white head and nice lacing. Aroma is of bourbon, vanilla and coffee. Body is full and slightly crisp. Alcohol, caramel malt, bourbon, vanilla and coffee fill the mouth. Finish is long and peppery. Very nice brew.

Tap at Harrys Hofbrau in San Jose. Coffee grinds dominate aroma. Hazy golden-orange with moderate white head that lingers as a creamy ring. Taste is astringent coffee and bakers chocolate. Thinish mouthfeel.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a rich golden color with very little head and moderate lacing. Nose is coffee, surprisingly, because the beer is so light in color. The nose also has some very nice bourbon notes. Taste is very rich, coffee and bourbon. Great beer!

Pours hazy golden with a one finger head, This is a weird one but very good. Aroma of coffee, Belgian funk, and cracker malts. Taste is a really nice herbal saison with coffee notes. And the golden color is deceptive. Medium body, really tasty beer.
Slight haze to an amber pour. Small off white head. Little lacing. Aroma of coffee and yeast. Taste is a dry alcoholic yeasty coffee.

Pours a burnt golden color with a white head. Coffee, caramel, toffee, biscuit, floral, molasses and bourbon aroma and flavors. Medium body and carbonation with a coffee, molasses, caramel and bourbon finish.

Draft Pours a slightly hazy orange golden color with a thick two finger foam. Nose is sweet belgian candi sugar,coconut some rustic grain and fresh coffee beans. Palate follows with a mix of sweet tripel notes, soft coffee adds a earthy layer and also quite a bit of complexity but not sure Im quite excited about this final product. Interesting to try just a bit weird and different for me to enjoy it for anything more than a fun exbeeriment. Paired with the right dish I could see this working better just not sure what that dish is...

Pours a hazy yellow-gold with white head. Has a faint aroma of bourbon, wheat, yeast and hits of coffee. A mix of flavors including citrus, wheat, yeast, spices, a dark alcohol flavor and a hint of coffee at the end - but not overwhelming. Unimpressed with the beer and not as strong as I expected.
Tap at Beer Authority, New York. Colour is cloudy golden with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Coffee, sweetness, alcohol, some fruits and malts. Have to say but I dont like this at all.
Coffee beer, not so interesting but unobjectionable. Dark, a decent cold brewed coffee. On tap at Griffon two.

On tap at The Reservoir, Waterbury, VT, this was poured into a tulip.
The appearance was a hazy burnt orange color with a bar pours kind of slim little head, quickly dissipates and leaves barely any lacing.
The smell started off with boozy bourbon sweetness running into the normal qualities of a Tripel or in this case Curieux and then as it warms, the coffee comes out nice and sweet. The differences of the sweet coffee (cold pressing) to the tripel qualities of iced apples and sweet breadiness really come together well and make it a really nice aroma.
The taste was moderately sweet through the Curieux qualities. Bourbon sits back a bit more in the flavor and gives off a slight sweet blend in the aftertaste. Semi-sticky finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a medium on the body with a nice semi-smooth feel to it. I think that cold pressed coffee was a great idea as it really felt great all around.
Overall, well, there ya go, Allagash taking an already stellar beer to the next level. Of course, Id have this again.

On tap at the Library Alehouse in Santa Monica. Hazy yellow appearance with a white head and thin lacing. Aroma of light coffee, Belgian notes, oak, vanilla, a touch of fruity esters and a hint of bourbon. Similar flavor, adding a light herbal-like bitterness over a medium body. Pretty nice overall.
Peach pour, small white head. Aroma of whiskey, roast, smoke, leather, hibiscus and lavender. Flavor is awesome; bourbon, oak,banana, peach, dark chocolate and vanilla.

Pours slightly hazy golden with a fine-bubbled ivory head. Aroma is not strong, but promises with fruity and subtle hoppy-hay notes. Bold flavor has fruity, bourbon and coffee tones with a malty under-note. Sharp mouthfeel delights with firm body and robust fizz. Jimmy Bean - James Bean!

Sampled at Midwest Belgian Beer Fest 2015 - Pours hazy yellow with a huge white head. The aroma has coffee, cocoa nibs, rich tripel malt and minor boubon. It has a medium / full body with soft carbonation. The flavor has lots of coffee, chocolate and lots of smooth rich malt with the abbey ale slant. Rich and delicious.
A strange combo of a traditional Belgian and coffee flavors. Liked it, but dont think I could do too much of that one.

Draft at Parker Pie. Hazy golden. Aroma of coffee and bourbon, some yeast as well. Flavours are candy sugar, light roast coffee, oak and some bourbon heat. Really interesting combination on a style ive certainly never seen before.

on tap at La Trappe in San Francisco; cloudy amber color; smoky bourbon aroma; lots of bourbon in the flavor; also some smoky vanilla and oak notes and spicy, mild Belgian yeast notes; an excellent bee

Keg at Top Hops - NYC. Pours mostly clear gold with a frothy, white topping. The nose holds some fresh coffee, pale malts, bread. Medium sweet flavor with notes of toffee, some citrus, coffee. Full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Warming finish with subtle cocoa, coffee beans, orange. Good one.

EBF
Pours slightly hazy golden with low white head. Aroma is of spices, coriander, bananas, citrus. Taste is of spices (lots), bananas, belgian yeast, citrus, fruits. Some bitterness. Palate: Medium-full bodied, medium carbonation. Overall: Quite spicy. Good.
One of a large number of samples I had at the Extreme Beer Fest in Boston 3/21/32014. Big sweet nice bourbon note!

Draft at Frisco Tap House in Columbia, MD served in a goblet; cloudy light-coppered golden color with white head. Aroma notes of wood, cappuccino, pale malt sweetness, light spices and vanilla. Taste adds dark coffee, sugar sweetness, oak char, fruity hops and Belgian yeast. Heavy-medium body, low carbonation, creamy, dry with woody sweet coffee finish. Interesting sipper, need to try the base to compare.
Draft at Mudville 9 NYC . Light tan color. Easy drinking with a boozy taste and finish. This is a light sipper

On tap @ SLL. Pours a cloudy copper color with a foamy white head that settles to a thin film and leaves lots of lace. Smell is of malt, grain, caramel, toffee, honey, coffee bean, and yeast aromas. Tastes of caramel, toffee, coffee bean, vanilla, and slight bourbon flavors on the finish. There is a mild amount of roast bitterness and an alcohol kick on the palate. Has a nice coffee presence but it is somewhat muted against the barrel aged qualities. Has a moderate level of carbonation with a crisp mouthfeel.

On tap @ Yard House. Slightly hazed golden orange pour with a white head. Lots of coffee and condensed milk on the nose. A bit of banana and lots off caramel. Some orange peel ones through as well. The flavor is pretty sweet. A bunch of coffee, cream, some coriander spiciness, and orange. Hints of booze and bourbon, maybe a little vanilla. Not bad.

Aromas of apples and stonefruit, subtle clean coffee, honey, toasted coconut, vanilla. Hazy orange with a mostly lasting pillowy white head. Fruity, bready, subtle clove, aftertaste is faint coffee. Medium bodied.

Pours an opaque yellow color with a coffee aroma. Taste is rich coffee flavor which is surprising because of its light apperance. A slight bourbon tinge on the palate after the swallow. The coffee flavor overwhelms this beer and is flavorful and tasty. A d elicous beer for the style, unique with the coffee taste.

5 dec 2014, tap. Light orange and mildly hazy. Nose is sweet black coffee. Med body and mildly fizzy. Granola malt, mildly fizzy, slightly astringent sweet black coffee. Alcohol isn't very noticeable.

4 oz draft pour at ChurchKeys Allagash 5th Anniversary event. Hazy golden brown with off-white head. Aromas of sweet coffee, spices, caramel. Tastes of sweet coffee, herbs, spices, caramel. Medium body with a dry finish. Coffee dominates, cant say Ive had a bourbon barrel aged tripel with coffee added but it works well.
Pours hazy golden yellow with thin head. Smell is bourbon and malt. Taste is vanilla, bourbon,and a hint of coffee with nice malt balance. Medium body light carbonatin.

Draft at Mekong. Pours golden with a thin white head. Smells of wood and alcohol. The coffee notes come out more on the tongue though the blend with the triple base makes for a strange pairing. It does hide the alcohol fairly well on the tongue. Finishes clean.
10 on on tap at Tylers, Durham. Hazy orange golden with a lasting film of cream. Nose is whiskey, caramel, charred oak. Taste is the same goodness. Medium body has low-medium carbonation.

Hazy golden in color.... Aroma of light coffee, bourbon, vanilla... Flavor is light roasted coffee with prevalent vanilla, bourbon... Coffee is notable throughout, still get some candi sugar and citrus, but somewhat blunted by coffee and bourbon... Nice beer, like curieux better

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bourbon barrel comes through in the aroma and right off the bat in the beginning, almost too much for me.

On tap at Mekong, Richmond. Pours a hazy golden orange/brown, whitish edge head and moderate lacing. Aroma is rich coffee upfront, followed by tripel complexity. Flavor is bold coffee mixed with tripel characteristics, oak, tropical fruit and vanilla. These flavor shouldnt mix, but they do. Wow, this is unique, and I look forward to seeing it again.

On tap @ Top Hops w/ Leighton. Pours a slightly hazy gold with med white head. Nose is full of big bourbon, chocolate, coffee, wood. Flavor is full of Jim Beam, especially on the back end.. warm finish. Pretty big fan.

Draft at Mekong. Poured gold, nice head, a bit hazy. Aroma was vanilla, slight Belgian spice, sweet pale malts, and a hint of coffee. Flavor matched, with the coffee reminding me a bit of a Starbucks blonde roast. Plays oddly, But not badly, with the base barrel aged tripel. Odd, but interesting and pretty good.
On tap at Taps in Petaluma. Pours a hazy golden color with a bit of head. Intense coffee that mellows out the bourbon but over powers a little.

murky tan tea, thin white ring. Cleaning product lemon and buttery coffee nose, low acidity but metallic and fizzy. Caramel and orange sweetness cut at front by bitter coffee finish, confused by heavy carbonation, foamy. Sweet across mid, coffee drowning out banana into sticky, dark grain bread finish. Yeast all over, messy combos. Confusing.

[ Keg ][ 8oz ][ The Industry Philly ][ $7 ][ Mini Wine Glass ][ 6.7.14 ]
>> Cloudy deep orange pour, okay white foam. Nice maple bourbon nose, sticky buttery bourbon, Belgian yeast...gives it a bit of a De Dolle Stille Nacht aroma. Flashes of blonde roast coffee make this quite interesting. Taste is mild soap, harsher bitterness, sticky, mild blonde roast coffee. Fairly nice. Definitely unique.
UPDATED: NOV 14, 2016 Draft at Khyber Pass. Hazy blonde pour. Tastes much different than it looks. Strong coffee. Warm bourbon flavors. Vanilla caramel underneath. Good stuff but not overly complex.
Easy to sip, pulling the maltiness forward in a roasted taste. The aroma was equally heady with concentrates of malt and breadiness.

Draft. Gold with a fluffy white head. Aroma is buttery, Belgian yeast and just a slight hint of coffee. Taste confirms what I can only assume is a diacetyl infection. Buttered popcorn carries the day with hints of what was supposed to have happened in the background, including the bourbon barrel and coffee. Very nice soft mouthfeel. Would like to try non-infected because it's still pretty drinkable in this state.

Sample at pour house during Maine event , pours golden with loosely bubbled head not much lacing. Aromas and flavor were lots of espresso, roast, pepper, fruit, Belgian malts, and yeast. Refreshing but it is a little thin.

A hazed golden amber ale with a thin lacing off white head. In aroma, smooth coffee grind with light fruity notes, coriander, very perfumy and nice. In mouth, a nice sweet fruity malt with loads of coffee extract, herbaceous hops, licorice and smooth warming alcohol. On tap at Porter Beer Bar.

Comes together ok but not huge - honestly I dont think espresso has a place in this style. Pours golden orange with good head and lacing. Espresso isnt huge at least, but dampens the coriander and other elements. Soft carbonation. Improves a little after a few tastes. Tap at Churchkey.

Shared at CK with gendv138 and solidfunk. Thanks! Nice golden color with a small white head on it. Aroma is lots of fresh ground coffee notes, some woody bourbon notes to it. Coffee is not muted all that much, which is quite nice. Coffee and bourbon - what a way to start a morning, right? Probably, probably not. Nicely infused and good balance between the bourbon and beer.
Tap at Maxs. Golden bodied. Massive coffee tones. Full bodied. Really strong oak and coffee notes. Massive flavor. Nice golden malt backbone. Right on.

On tap at Capitol Beer& Tap Room. Pours golden with a thick off-white head and a coffee aroma. There is a hearty caramel malt flavor with lots of coffee and a hint of bourbon. It tastes like it should be a dark beer because of the coffee. Very unique and delicious.
Pours a hazy amber with a foamy white head. Smells of yeasty fruit, hint of funk hint of pear. Taste is bitter and sweet - hint of sour - fruit and coffee, biscuits.
Draught from the evening star. Orange brown pour. Light coffee, dark fruits, sugar, vanilla really. Good.

On tap at Joe Canals West Deptford.
Appearance: Milky hazy orange amber body with a short white head that quickly dissipates.
Aroma: The aroma is very odd, vanilla creamer, roasted peanuts, hints of coffee, and a touch of bourbon.
Taste: Bourbon runs mildly through a creamy slightly fruit tripel. Vanilla works through it with banana leading to a heavily creamer coffee/roasted peanut finish. The finish lingers a touch of booze with bourbon. Its an odd mix, but it works.
Palate: Creamy with moderate carbonation.
Overall: This is excellently executed despite being an odd concept. This is balanced through the flavors nicely and despite some of them not being common together it works.
Draft. Enjoy the base beer but this oen seems to be just a bit off the rails, lots of clashing flavors, coffee is nice in the aroma though.
Draft at Torst. Pours cloudy yellow with white head. Nose and taste of coffee, lemongrass, light bourbon, oak and yeast. Medium body.

Draught at Publick House, 3/14/14Looks like Curieux, that is to say, bright golden with a hint of amber and a fluffy, well-retained head.Soft coffee in the nose still allows light peach/apricot esters and bourbon notes in. Almost a light vanilla-chocolate interplay and quite light on the alcohol. Fairly strong aroma and Im glad Im just smelling espresso....Deceptively beer-like in flavor. You certainly get the coffee up front, clean, lightly bitter and with plenty of vanilla flavor. However, malt kicks in, adding light sweetness with a touch of biscuity malt. Some lightly acidic notes along with yeast esters begin to give an almost citric-like impression as the bourbon and coffee sit somewhat dryly on the finish. Actually liked this a lot more than Curieux (which I dont care for much at all, thanks to the heavy bourbon), as the coffee blotted out some of the heavy bourbon character, added a silky-slickness to the texture and seemed to be in balance. Of course, you certainly lose a fair amount of the Belgian nature of the beer, but for what it is, I think it works fine.

On tap. A lot of promise held in the description of this beer and I was disappointed by the subtlety vs more of the big flavors. Ultimately, that's my issue. The flavor definitely carries some of the vanilla from the barrel, while allowing for an easier drinking experience.

On tap at Boulder Strong Ale Fest (2014). Pour is clear golden with a small white head and decent lacing. Huge coffee, lightly fruity, oaky, earthy, toffee, and caramelly aroma. Taste is espresso, spicy, fruity, bready, light caramel, and wood with a lightly bitter finish. Slick mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Pretty cool Belgian strong.

On tap at Avery Strong Ale Fest poured a hazy gold with a small lasting ivory head. Aromas of coffee, light caramel, light fruitiness and light oak. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a smooth dry finish. Flavors of coffee, caramel, light bourbon and light oak with a smooth dry lingering coffee finish.

On tap @ Boulder Strong Ale Fest 2014. Pours a bit hazy golden orange appearance with a thin white head. Aroma is pretty nutty. Some woody notes. A bit of coffee in the flavor. Caramel and toffee tastes. A bit of graham cracker. Kind of twangy. Kind of disappointing and honestly a big hard to see the underlying tripel.
Draft. Golden pour with beige head some light coffee, oak and some triple notes. Flavor is roasted and coffee with yeast and spices with some light barreled oak tones.

A- pours a hazy golden orange with a good off white head that ruins to a skin. Good lacing.

S- aroma of a porter. Dirty, chalky coffee and espresso, with some mild bourbon, vanilla, sugary bubble gum, and sweet tropical fruits that hide in the back. All somewhat muddled and not overwhelming. Some faint stinging alcohol. 

M- medium tacky body with a medium sweet palate and light carbonation. 

T- coffee, cola, malts and bourbon to start. Gets sweeter in the middle then bitter. Some sweetened tea. Grasses and lemon become prominent later. Ending is mineral water and zinc. Some light grapefruit and day old coffee grounds linger.

Pours a clear gold with a thick and creamy white head...nice lacing and retention. Aroma has light fruity notes and mild but obvious coffee. Flavor has nice light fruity notes and subtle spice with coffee mingling throughout but not dominating. Mouthfeel is light/medium and the finish is fruit/coffee/bourbon and warming.

Draft at Beer Run. Pours a hazy orange color with a large frothy off-white head. Good head retention. Aroma of coffee, coconut, wood, curry? The taste is big coffee notes, pale malts, whiskey, wood, spice. Medium bodied, lingering spice, good balance, high carbonation. Nice beer.

On tap and snifter served at Lunar Brewing Co., displaying a lightly hazed, orangey gold color, with some fair persistence to the soft white, silky head foam, and decent cling to the waves & spots of lacing. The aroma was expressive, roasty espresso, with some chocolate & syrupy sweetness on the back. The mocha notes faded for the most part in the flavor, as warming, bourbony alcohol, fruit, and subtle spice took center stage. Medium bodied, with some perky carbonation, moderate hop bitterness, with a smooth malt backing. Not too heavy, warming, but not too boozy, enjoyable & welcome, cold weather sipper.

Draft into a goblet. Pours gold with a very slight head like a nice golden tripel. But aroma is strong coffee with sugar, yeast, and spice. Taste is fresh, dark roast coffee with some fruit, sugar, spice. Surprisingly balanced. Wouldnt want to drink much of it at once....but pretty decent.

Draft sample at FOBAB 2013. Pours a hazy golden color without much of a head, just a small off-white ring. Tons and tons of coffee, especially on the aroma. Toasted and sweet and caramel malts, vanilla, brown sugar, maybe some oak, but plenty of whiskey.. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation. Toasty, malty, and boozy. Interesting beer. Not sure Id want more than a sample.

On tap at the Blind Tiger. Poured a golden color with a small sized head. Coffee was present in the aromas but subtle in the tastes. Would like to have seen the coffee carry over a bit more in the tastes.

Keg @ Beer Run. The pours deep gold with a small head. The nose is .mild earthy roast coffee. Honeyed apple. Sweet Belgian yeast. Golden Grahams. The taste is similar. The sweetness of he tripels balanced a bit by the bitterness from the coffee. Medium body, sort of oily. Soft carbonation. Overall, OK.
Lotta coffe offered on top of an old doughy sweet caramel booze dough. Whiskey vanilla dough offered. Too sweet. Coffee booze drink.
11/16/2013. On tap. Pours amber color with a white head. Coffee aromas with light fruit and malt. Coffee flavors somewhat takes over. This is not bad, but not my favorite.
On tap at Three Aces. Poured clear light amber. Pleasant coffee aroma. Quite smooth straight coffee light bourboness. Decent.

Draught at Breukelen Bier merchants. Pours golden with a nice soft initial head. Aroma is lots of coffee, chocolate Bourbon, molasses, light yeast, fruity end. Flavor has these but Belgian yeast and orchard fruit notes. Feel is thick. Really surprising how well it all works together.

Tap at the Bad Apple, Chicago. Poured a clear light amber with a round white head. The aroma is big coffee and alcohol. The flavour is medium bitter with a spicy hop pepper yeast malt alcohol palate. This beer has everything.

Draft sampled at The Bad Apple, Chicago. Pours clear dark golden with an off white head. Aroma of coffee upfront, suprising given the color, behind is the bourbon/vanilla with booze, toffee and caramel. Flavour is heavy sweet and light bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2014 Draft at 2sp..medium orange color.slight ring like head..nose dominated by the bourbon jim beam characteristics..not getting much coffee on the nose..mouthfeel is quite smooth with a roasty nut like presence..this tastes like a love child of a Belgian triple with a Caribbean like coffee stout..medium bodied finish and the heat from the booze is felt.glad to try but just seemed like an odd addition to the normal curiuex..eh....revisited really nice offering chock full of flavor..
Looks like a regular blond tripel, has some coffee to the nose. Taste is exactly like a frappucino...coffee, chocolate, vanilla, with a good mouthfeel and moderate finish. Really good.

On draft at the Big Hunt in DC. Pours a cloudy gold with an off white head. Light butterscotch aroma. Flavors of caramel with some smoky notes. Smooth mouth feel with moderate carbonation. Bitter finish.
On draft at the big hunt it is a cloudy yellow with a slight white head. The aroma is of coffee. The taste is coffee and some sweetness of bourbon. Very interesting.
Big coffee flavor up front. Some spice, clove, Belg yeast and coriander. Warming alcohol throughout. The coffee definitely dominates but the other flavors are noticeable as well.
draft at BCTC 2013. blonde yellow pour, fuller mouthfeel. Sweet maltiness, tripel sweetness, bourbon & coffee. coffee notes outshine bourbon IMO. strange combo but worked real well. Very nice

10oz pour at Bangers and lace. Unexpected coffee from a golden begian strong ale. It pours a hazy golden with a small beige head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, fresh pressed coffee and some dry crackery malts. Flavor brings out coffee even more and some wild yeast notes, Belgian yeast and some floral notes. Very smooth and light for the ABV. Finishes on dry-ish notes of coffee and Belgian yeast. Great stuff.
On tap at prohibition pig and is very interesting. Tastes like drinking a coffee light and sweet. Huge coffee flavor dominates with vanilla and sugary sweetness. Interesting for sure.

Draft @ Prohibition Pig. Aroma is nice fresh ground coffee bean and a bourbon undertone. Taste is mostly bold, intense coffee beans. Again bourbon comes through in nuances. Seems to have traces of the base brew underneath this coffee and bourbon. Lingering coffee after each sip. I really enjoy coffee infused beers, this happens to be a standout in my recent memory. And using a Tripel base with coffee is really interesting.

Draft at Prohibition Pig. Orange reddish hue
Cold pressed coffee and oak
Taste is big and bold. Bready with hints of medicinal quality. Coffee goes throughout from start to finish.

On tap last year at Church Key in Washington, DC (it was called Jim Bean, but it seems to be this beer). Wow! Never had coffee in my beer outside of a stout or porter. Haze golden with an orange tinge, white head, nice lacing. Nose is coffee coffee and more coffee. Some subtle belgian spices in the nose as well. Smooth drinking, awesome mouthfeel, a touch bitter, sweetness and then coffee in the finish.
Arôme de café très volatile, la pièce sest remplie rapidement. Le corps est somptueux et le café brutal sur un fini plus végétal, unique.
On draft at alagash tap takeover, way too much coffee, some bourbon flavors, but coffee dominates

From tap at the Festival. Clear gold pour with white head. Intense coffee aroma, vegetal notes but also roasty, definitely smells just like cold pressed coffee. Some light bourbony wood notes are perceptible, but barely. Very intense coffee flavor. The most peculiar part of this beer is that it has the palate of cold pressed coffee (plus carbonation), very silky mouthfeel with a long bitter aftertaste. Not my favorite beer, not sure Id drink a pint but this is very well made.

unique, it being a pale colored coffee flavored beer, as opposed to dark and roasty. the coffee aroma was very apparent, as was the coffee flavor. it was nicely sour, and also had some bitter bite. but i found those three main components kind of stood on their own and didnt quite meld. still, a very interesting and tasty sour ale.

Hazy, dark golden color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of citrus, spices, toast, vanilla, bourbon, roast, smoke and coffee malts. Taste of coffee, citrus, spices, vanilla, roast, bourbon, and light alcohol in the finish.

10 ounce pour - $6.00 at Leons Full Service in Decatur, Georgia as part of their Allagash Takeover event.

Appearance: Heavily hazed, darkened gold body with a nearly white head, just shy of a full inch.

Smell: My stars! Certainly a stronger coffee aroma than I had anticipated, delightfully roasty, nutty. Undertone of gently sweet-scented bourbon notes. Faintly fruity, with a bit of lemon, leaving little of the original tripel to recognize.

Taste: Sweetish flavor of roasted coffee beans -- it really does have a surprising depth of coffee in the taste. No, really, it does! Caramel, vanilla, and wooden bourbon accents follow. Then, way waaaay back is the original Allagash Tripel. Ultra faint citrus. Sweetish, coffee finish with a sliver of bourbon and a slight, warming alcohol quality.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-plus carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel.

Overall: I would enjoy starting my day by downing a pint of James Bean.
On tap at city beet pours yellow with white head. Taste is all coffee as well as the aroma.

Growler poured a clear yellow with no head

Smell and taste of coffee, hazlenut, nutella.  Abv is very well masked.

Sampled at the Raleigh Rare and Vintage Festival 2013.  Clear yellow pour with offwhite head ring.  Smells like a burning fuelsel alcohol and coffee.  Flavor is woody barrel and sage.  unusual to have coffee infused into an triple.  Not really my thing. Meh.

Pouring at the Saturday sessions of Extreme Beerfest.  Pours a clear gold with a thin white head.  Big whiskey and wood on the nose, toasty.  Medium bodied, soft smoke, toast and wood, lots of wood.  Hints of chocolate, lingering wood with some alcohol warmth on the finish.  Interesting.

Sampled at EBF.  Pours a hazy come with some creamy, white head.  Big coffee nose, chocolate, caramel, malt.  Smells and tastes like coffee.  Other flavors of brown sugar, nuts, a little maple, sugary.  Full bodied, but dry, nutty finish.  I was surprised by this on many levels.  Doesnt taste like it looks.

Tap at Brewers Choice.  Pours hazy orange.  Nice aromas of fresh roasted coffee and vanilla.  you get lots of coffee upfront kinda overpowering.  also get some vanilla, straw, pineapple, peat, yeast, ginger, and some sweet bourbon.  kinda ll over the place with alcohol warming on finish

Pizzeria Paradiso, Alexandria tap: Pours a light coppery color with a white head. Aroma is straight up coffee beans (ground up and fresh), with a little bit of whiskey, and somewhere deep in there is a tripel. Taste is straight up coffee beans, which is pretty crazy, because this beer looks nothing like what it tastes. Vanilla is present as well. This beer is just nuts and even weirder than the Curieux.

On tap 4 oz. sample at Pizza Paradiso in Alexandria, VA.

Hazy, golden oak color with small off-white head and very good lacing.

Aroma of sweet light malt, vanilla, light fruit and fresh whiskey barrel with nary  a hint of coffee.

Taste of sweet light malt, sweet alcohol, light fruit, vanilla and no coffee.

Medium body and medium carbonation.

So where did the coffee go?!!  If it is there, it is very subtle.  The Jim Beam is certainly there and makes for a wonderful beer.  I wonder if they served me Curieux by mistake.  I certainly would have rated this beer higher if I had not been expecting coffee. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at Maxs. Looks like a light sour beer. Smells exactly like coffee. Tastes like coffee beans and bourbon : )

Tap. Pours hazy golden amber with average, fizzy white head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is coffee, bread and cereal malts, earthy hops, figs, leather, and light roasted malts. Flavor is coffee, roasted malts, faint earthy hops, dark fruit esters, vanilla, and oak; bourbon undertones throughout with a dry finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

Tap at Maxs Taphouse.  Pours lightly hazy gold with a, fizzy white head, short retention with good lacing.  Aroma is coffee and earthy hops with cereal and cookie malt.  Flavor is malt forward with alcohol notes, earthy coffee and hops with medium fruity esters and a sweet finish.  Medium body and carbonation.

Boo-yeah! Numero quatro! Soft pale blonde pour.  Nose shows coffee (lots o coffee) and a touch of bourbon with lightly fruity notes showing in the background.  Coffee is definitely there in the flavor with a touch of bourbon and white fruit.  Coffee definitely the primary flavor here but I really enjoyed this one.  

Side note: At this point 4 people have rate this beer and 2 were from Church Key and 2 were from Raleigh Rare Beer Fest.  At each location one person rated the beer a 3 and one person rated the beer a 3.8.

Tap at rrbf.  Pours a hazy orange golden with a small fizzy white head.  Nose is strong coffee, lightly bitter, toned down bourbon, some fruity notes.  Flavor is similar and very one-demensional with the simple coffee notes overpowering everything.  Kind of a letdown for Allagash.

The aroma is smooth coffee, hazelnuts.  The appearance is slightly hazy yellow/orange, white head.  The flavor is strongly coffee, hazelnut.  The finish is just like the flavor.  I couldnt get past the coffee or the hazelnut flavors to find anything else.  Still, I enjoyed this.
Draft. Pours golden orange with an off white head. Hazelnuts, coffee, and peaches. I have no idea what just happened.

Draft at barcade during their anniversary party. Pours a glowing hazy orange body with thin white lacing. Aroma is pepper and coffee, strange but nice  Mouthfeel is medium with notes of coffee, fruit, citrus, spice and peppers. Interesting.

tap Barcade: This beer deserves a category all on its own. Pour is peach toned. The nose is hazelnuts, peanuts, green coffee and some pepper. Taste is sweet with light coffee, peanut butter and caramel. Smooth, creamy body. Coffee, nutty overtones. hardly any belgian flavors to speak of. Odd but good.

Tap at Barcade. Very little coffee influence. Mid orange pour. Big, yeasty nose, a little vanilla latte. Full, mid-sweet body, oak, bubblegum, with coffee in the midbody. Surprisingly quaffable. Coffee is light but balanced.

Draft at Churchkey. Pours a hazy straw, small bubbly head. Nose and flavor are strange and dont quite work with me, with strange coffee notes interfering with the Curieux concept of barrel-aged tripel. The lovely combination of bread, stone fruit, and tannins are masked by a bitter espresso character. Not a fan.

Draft at Churchkey. Murky orange gold color, small white edge head, solid lacing. Aroma of intense freshly roasted coffee beans. Taste is smooth coffee, vanilla, straw, pineapple. Coffee and whiskey, and interesting mix.
